questions.text: During recovery from anaesthesia, which of the following drugs is used for the reversal of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neostigmine
Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor commonly used during reversal of anaesthesia.

Reversal agents commonly used in clinical practice:
Cholinesterase inhibitors – Neostigmine (most common), edrophonium, and pyridostigmine. Sugammadex, a cyclodextrin, is the first selective relaxant binding agent for rocuronium and vecuronium. L-cysteine causes the inactivation of gantacurium.

questions.text: 70-year-old smoker presents with high grade fever, cough and confusion with diarrhea. CXR shows bilateral infiltrates in both lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Na= 126 mEq/ L, AST-62, ALT 56, RBS -112 mg/di and serum Bilirubin 0.8 mg%. Which of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Explanation : This is a case of pneumonia + diarrhea = Legionella Pneumonia + hemolytic anemia = Mycoplasma

questions.text:
A 24-year-old female patient presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. On examination neck rigidity is present and there is hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck. A lumbar puncture was done and CSF findings are as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
Opening pressure – Increased
Colour- Cloudy white
PMN-85%
CSF/serum glucose ratio – 0.2
Sugar-30 mg/dl
Protein – 200 mg/dl
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bacterial meningitis
The given clinical picture of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, vomiting with neck rigidity, hip, and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck (Brudzinsky’s sign), and CSF examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis.
The most common organism causing bacterial meningitis in adults is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Other less common causes are Neisseria meningitidis, Staphylococcus aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Haemophilus sp., and Enterobacteriaceae, etc.

questions.text: If wide range of values are present in a community then best measure of Central tendency will be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Median is best measure of central tendency when outlier is present in data i.e wide range of values. • Mean: Most commonly used central tendency. Also it is most affected when outliers are present • Median: most commonly used when outliers are present • Mode: least affected by outliers

questions.text: A male patient aged 68 years comes to the emergency room with a feeling of impending doom and palpitations. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is your diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anteroseptal MI
The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic patient suffered from drug-induced hypoglycemia. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for her hypoglycemic episode?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Glimepride

Among the following options, Glimepiride which is a sulphonylurea is known to cause hypoglycemia.
Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that also stimulates insulin secretion. They bind to a specific site on the ẞ cell K-ATP channel complex and inhibit its activity. This causes cell membrane to depolarize and leads to a cascade of events resulting in insulin secretion.

questions.text: Which of following is cause of exudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Explanation : exudative pleural effusion i.e. inflammation = Rheumatoid arthritis Transudate pleural effusion : MCC ? Cardiac failure Nephrotic syndrome Hepatic hydrothorax Peritoneal dialysis Hypothyroidism

questions.text: At what CD4 count is Kaposi sarcoma likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Less than 200/μL

The likelihood of developing Kaposi sarcoma increases when absolute CD4 lymphocyte count is Less than 200/μL. Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is very common in patients suffering from acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). KS is considered to be an AIDS-defining disease.

questions.text: According to the American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) classification, what grade is given to a normal healthy individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ASA I
A normal healthy individual is given ASA I grade.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac biomarkers is the earliest to rise after acute myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myoglobin

Myoglobin is the earliest to rise in acute MI followed by CK- MB, troponin and then LDH.

questions.text:
A woman arrived at the hospital with edema, visual disturbances, and heart failure after consuming a food item purchased from a seller who has now been arrested for food adulteration. Which of the following is the most likely food adulterant used?
Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sanguinarine
The clinical presentation of edema, visual disturbances, and heart failure after consuming a food item purchased from a seller who has now been arrested for food adulteration is suggestive that Sanguinarine is the toxic compound responsible for this.
Sanguinarine causes Epidemic Dropsy.
- Contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil. 
- Toxic compound: Sanguinarine

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with past history of tuberculosis was brought to the emergency department with complaints of breathing difficulty. On examination, there is shortness of breath, and prominent neck veins. While recording the patient’s blood pressure, a significant drop in systolic pressure during inspiration was noted from 80mmHg to 60mmHg. The X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cardiac tamponade
The given clinical scenario of breathing difficulty, prominent neck veins, pulsus paradoxus (significant drop in blood pressure >10 mm Hg), and X-ray image showing cardiomegaly (cardiothoracic ratio more than 0.5) in a patient with a past history of tuberculosis is suggestive of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Intravenous induction agent of choice for day care anesthesia is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Propofol

Intravenous induction agent of choice for day care anesthesia is propofol.
- It has rapid onset of action and a faster recovery.
- It also reduces postoperative nausea and vomiting which provide yet another reason for it to be a preferred drug for outpatient anesthesia.

questions.text: Due to increase in lung cancer cases in India, government started Tobacco control act (COTPA), which level of prevention?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Primary prevention tobacco control act is primary prevention

questions.text: A health worker goes house to house every 15 days taking fever history and preparing slides. Which form of surveillance is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Active surveillance: data is collected by visiting house to house • Passive surveillance: data is collected in health facility • Sentinel surveillance: data is collected from different sentinel sites

questions.text: Counselling and Screening is done for Tuberculosis in a HIV positive patient at ICTC Centre (NACP program). This is which level of prevention?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Screening of disease is secondary prevention

questions.text: Handwashing during COVID 19 is what level of prevention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Hand washing is primary prevention

questions.text: Match the auscultatory areas of the heart from image given below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1-Aortic, 2-Pulmonary, 3- Tricuspid, 4-Mitral
The image shows the auscultation areas of the heart and option B is correctly matched.
The auscultation areas correspond to the areas where the sounds and murmurs of the heart valves can be best heard.
- Mitral area- At the apex of the heart which is at the 5th Intercostal space in the midclavicular line.
- Tricuspid area- Lower left sternal edge in the left 4th intercoastal space.
- Pulmonic area-Upper left sternal edge in the left 2nd intercoastal space
- Aortic area- Upper right sternal edge in the right 2nd intercoastal space.

questions.text: A male smoker patient who has difficulty in swallowing is most likely to develop which of the following!
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Explanation : Squamous cell cancer Lung cancer seen in smoker is usually Small cell carcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma. Option b and c mean the same and are seen in nonsmokers. Option d is also seen in non-smoker and presents with paraneoplastic manifestation of gynecomastia.

choices.text: Anticipate a difficult airway for endotracheal intubation
Evaluate a patient for orogastric intubation
Evaluate the risk of blood loss during surgery
Evaluate the cardiovascular fitness of the patient

questions.text: Malampatti classification is used to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anticipate a difficult airway for endotracheal intubation
The modified Mallampatti classification is used in the assessment of airway. It is a predictor of the difficulty of intubation or difficult airway.
The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without saying “ahh.”

questions.text: A gym owner noticed that people who come to the gym also drink iced tea. He concluded that drinking iced tea is the sole reason to lose weight. What is this relationship called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Spurious

In the gym owner’s case, concluding that iced tea alone causes weight loss is a spurious relationship because it ignores other key factors like exercise and overall diet.
A spurious relationship Is when two variables appear to be connected but are actually linked by another factor or are coincidental. In this scenario, the gym owner observed that gym-goers also drink iced tea and concluded that iced tea is the sole cause of weight loss. However, this conclusion is just coincidental because it ignores other important factors, such as exercise, diet, and lifestyle changes, which likely contribute to weight loss.

questions.text: A smoker had developed blood-tinged sputum during cough. On work up Chest X-ray was normal. Which of the following is the next procedure done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Explanation : Smoker + hemoptysis, if chest x-ray is normal, next step should be – CT chest Later – bronchoscopy

questions.text: HIV positive patient develops lung infection. His CD4 count is less than 100cells/ cu.mm and sputum shows acid-fast organism. Which of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Explanation : Acid fast organism : Mycobacterium avium and Nocardia But CD4 count is less than 100 cells/cu.mm – Mycobacterium avium is more common.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is on bed rest since 10 days. He develops sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain. Which of the follow
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Explanation : a bed rest patient with breathlessness and chest pain we should think of pulmonary embolism. IOC – CT pulmonary angiography.

questions.text: A young man presented with severe muscle weakness and ptosis. Chest X-ray revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Further investigation reveals the presence of AchR antibodies. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Myasthenia gravis

The given clinical scenario of weakness, ptosis, anterior mediastinal mass (thymoma), and the presence of AchR antibodies are suggestive of myasthenia gravis.
Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder due to autoimmune damage to the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ. It is characterized by weakness and muscle fatigue. Weakness increases with usage and muscle movement is difficult at the end of the day. It affects proximal muscles leading to weakness of the limbs. Ocular features like ptosis and diplopia can also be seen. Myasthenia gravis is often related to thymomas. Symptoms of myasthenia gravis improve after excision of the thymus gland even in the absence of a thymoma.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient consuming alcohol for the last 20 years had his last drink 3 days back. He presents with altered sensorium, disorientation, tremors, and a feeling of insects crawling over his body. Which of the following should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lorazepam + thiamine

The given clinical scenario of alcohol withdrawal with altered sensorium, and a feeling of insects crawling over his body points towards the diagnosis of delirium tremens. Lorazepam + thiamine should be given to this patient.
Delirium tremens is treated using benzodiazepines like lorazepam starting with a higher dosage which is gradually tapered as withdrawal symptoms disappear. In cases of chronic alcohol use, vitamin deficiency (especially thiamine) may be co-existing and hence bolus doses of thiamine are given to prevent/treat Wernicke encephalopathy.

questions.text: You are the intern posted in the emergency department. You came across an ABG report given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Metabolic acidosis
The given ABG report shows decreased blood arterial PH(Normal range: 7.35-7.45), and decreased HCO3 levels (Normal: 22-28 mEq/L) indicating metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: In 14' century there was a disease called plague, for how many days ship and all passengers were kept under quarantine
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 40 days Quarantine term derives from “quaranta giorni,” meaning 40 days, In 14th century when plaque pandemic was devastating Europe. As a form of protection, it was declared that all ships and people had to be isolated for 40 days before entering the city.

Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: TB sputum assesment comes under which type of mode of prevention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

TB sputum analysis is screening of disease and this is secondary prevention

questions.text: A 47-year-old chronic alcoholic was brought-with complaints of confusion and agitation. Her husband reports that she had consumed excessive alcohol the previous day. On examination, she had difficulty in walking and horizontal nystagmus was noted. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

IV thiamine

The given scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with confusion, agitation, horizontal nystagmus, and a history of recent heavy alcohol intake is suggestive of Wernicke’s encephalopathy.
The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke’s encephalopathy is to give thiamine (vitamin B1) 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

questions.text: What ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is given during CPR in an adult if 2 rescuers are present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

30:2
During cardiopulmonary resuscitation of adults, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 irrespective of the number of rescuers.
In infants and children, the ratio is 30:2 for a single rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present.

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agents act on NMDA receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ketamine

Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that inhibits NMDA (N- methyl-D-aspartate) receptors resulting in a decrease in excitatory stimulation by glutamate in the brain. It is a strong analgesic and amnestic agent.

On the cardiovascular system, it directly has a cardio- depressive effect and indirectly stimulates it by activating the sympathetic system and inhibiting the vagus nerve. It predominantly shows a stimulatory effect hence causing tachycardia, increased cardiac output, and increased systemic and pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy who is a known case of cerebral palsy, was brought to the OPD for a routine check-up. The child had a past history of weakness in both upper and lower limbs which improved with time. On examination, residual weakness is present more in the lower limbs and trunk as compared to the upper limbs. What is this condition called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Spastic diplegia
The given clinical scenario of a child with cerebral palsy, who has residual weakness in his lower limbs as compared to his upper limbs is highly suggestive of spastic diplegia.
Spastic diplegia is more commonly seen in premature infants with a history of birth asphyxia due to damage to immature white matter. It is 2nd most common type of cerebral palsy in India after spastic quadriplegia. Both the lower limbs are involved. During development, characteristic commando crawling is seen. Brain MRI shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter with compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles. IQ of these children is usually normal and has a good prognosis.

questions.text: A study Is conducted to identify the association between vaccination and the development of a disease in a community. Based on the data, 6 vaccinated individuals and 12 unvaccinated individuals developed severe disease. Calculate the relative risk for this community.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

0.5
The relative risk in this case will be 0.5.
Relative risk is the ratio of the incidence of disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non- exposed. It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between suspected cause and effect in a cohort study.
Here,
Incidence of disease among exposed (Vaccinated) = 6
Incidence of disease among non-exposed (Unvaccinated) = 12
Relative risk (RR) = Incidence exposed/incidence unexposed = 6/12=0.5

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with fever, poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, a bulging fontanelle was observed. CSF analysis revealed gram-stained microorganisms, neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and reduced glucose concentrations. Which is the most common neurological sequel of this condition that can develop?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sensorineural hearing loss
The clinical features of poor feeding, fever, seizures, bulging fontanelle (due to raised ICP), and lethargy with the mentioned CSF findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis, and sensorineural hearing loss is the most common sequelae which can develop in cases of bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is being treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and comes for follow-up. He is tachypneic with a resting oxygen saturation of 86%. Which of the following will increase the survival In this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Long term oxygen therapy
Long-term oxygen therapy will increase survival in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
Supplemental oxygen is indicated in patients with resting 02 saturation of ≤88% or ≤89% with signs of pulmonary arterial hypertension or right heart failure. It has been proven to prolong survival and the benefits are directly proportional to the duration of oxygen administration (hours per day). Studies did not show significant benefits in patients with moderate hypoxemia.

questions.text: In a given population, 4050 live births were recorded over a period of 1 year. Among these, 50 were stillbirths, 50 died in the 1st week of life and 150 died within 8-28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

49.38

The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) of the given population is 49.38 per 1000 live births.
Neonatal mortality rate = No. of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year
In this population, there were 4050 live births.
NMR (50+150) x 1000/4050 = 100/2 = 49.38

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Explanation : Asbestosis = MC lung cancer(Adeno Ca.) Most specific will be Mesothelioma

questions.text: What is the level of prevention when a person receives penicillin injections for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Secondary
Receiving penicillin injections for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease is Secondary prevention.
Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

questions.text: A pregnant woman, after undergoing a cesarean section under spinal anesthesia, had a headache that aggravated in sitting position. Which of the following is not advised for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased water intake
The given scenario is suggestive of post-dural puncture headache which worsens with increased water intake.
Post-dural puncture headache is believed to result from a puncture of the dura (unintentional or intentional) in the setting of neuraxial anesthesia. This causes leakage of CSF from a dural defect leading to intracranial hypotension.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of anemia in-a 65-year-old male?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Iron deficiency anemia
The most common type of anaemia in a 65-year-old male is iron deficiency anemia (IDA). It is also the most common type of nutritional anemia in India.

questions.text: A patient undergoing elbow surgery was given a local anaesthetic during the procedure. Local anaesthetics acts by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Blocking voltage gated sodium channels
Local anaesthetics primarily act by blocking the voltage- gated sodium channels bound to the membrane.
Sodium channels have one larger a subunit and one or two smaller ẞ subunits. These voltage-gated sodium channels exist in 3 states:
- Resting (non-conducting)
- Open (conducting)
- Inactivated (non-conducting)

questions.text: Child has developed recurrent lung infections with thickened sputum and CXR shows bronchial wall thickening. He has been suffering from steatorrhea since birth. Which of the following is first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Explanation : Thick sputum + recurrent infections + bronchial wall thickening + bronchiectasis + steatorrhea these are typical findings of Cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis : abnormality in chloride channel encoded by the CFTR gene because of this there will be very thick secretions. Thick secretions will not allow the pancreas to work properly so there will be pancreatic insufficiency, because of pancreatic insufficiency there will be steatorrhea.

choices.text: Acetylcholine receptor and muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase antibodies

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with complaints of fatigue which worsens towards the end of the day. She also complains of double vision while watching television. The physician suspects a case of myasthenia gravis. Which of the following tests has the highest sensitivity in diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Single-fiber electromyography

Single-fiber electromyography has the highest sensitivity in the clinical diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.
Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) simultaneously records action potentials of two muscle fibers innervated by the same motor axon. The variability in time of the second action potential relative to the first is called “jitter” and this is increased in myasthenia gravis. It is the most sensitive test used for the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

choices.text: Inhibition of the T-type calcium channels

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented with frequent episodes of staring spells in school. On further evaluation, she was diagnosed with absence seizures and started on ethosuximide. What is the mechanism of action of this drug? GABA: gamma-Aminobutyric acid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Inhibition of the T-type calcium channels
Ethosuximide, commonly used in children suffering from absence seizures acts by inhibiting T-type calcium channels.
Absence seizures originate in the thalamus and produce the pathognomonic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG. This pattern is produced due to the intrinsic properties of the low threshold T-type calcium channels of the thalamus. These channels are activated at a much lower threshold and produce larger currents as compared to most other calcium channels in the brain. Hence, inhibition of these T-type calcium currents in the neurons of the thalamus by ethosuximide is effective for the management of absence seizures.

questions.text: A patient developed hand-foot syndrome after 10 days of initiation of chemotherapy. Which of the following is the most likely agent to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Capecitabine
Capecitabine is commonly associated with the side effect of hand-foot syndrome.
Capecitabine is a pyrimidine analog that is classified as an antimetabolite agent. Side effects are diarrhea, hand-foot syndrome, and myelosuppression.
Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia consists of erythema, desquamation, pain, and sensitivity to touch of the palms and soles.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Imatinib

Imatinib is the drug of choice for gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).
Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It has a dominant role in tumors involving ABL, KIT, or EGFR kinases. It is the chemotherapy agent of choice in the chronic phase of chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML) and GIST.

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with a 5-day history of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. Chest X-ray is normal. Which of the following will be the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Co-trimoxazole only

The clinical scenario of an HIV-infected patient with a CD4 count of 200/mm³ with fever, cough, and a normal chest X- ray is indicative of underlying Pneumocystis pneumonia. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It is treated with co-trimoxazole.
Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

choices.text: Incidence will increase and prevalence will decrease
Incidence and prevalence are not related to it
Incidence will decrease and prevalence will increase

questions.text: Morbidity of a disease is on the rise. Which of the following statements is correct with respect to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Incidence and prevalence will increase

The incidence and prevalence will increase when the morbidity increases.
Morbidity refers to any deviation, whether subjective or objective, from a state of physical well-being. It encompasses conditions such as sickness, illness, and disability. Morbidity is typically measured by morbidity rates or ratios, which include frequency, duration, and severity. Disease frequency is indicated by incidence and prevalence rates.

choices.text: It is more common on the dorsal aspect of the hand
X ray imaging will aid in location of the foreign body in all patients.
Oral analgesics are the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with severe pain and swelling in her right hand which is increasing in size and severity. She had a prick injury while in the garden 5 days back. On examination, she cries out in pain when you try to extend the hand and palpate the palmar aspect passively. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 It requires incision and drainage.
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a deep palmar abscess secondary to a foreign body and it requires incision and drainage.
Foreign body intrusions into the hand are among the most common injuries to the upper extremity seen in the Emergency Department. They can present with pain and swelling initially. The patient also presents with partial foreign bodies after the partial removal of the object. The delayed presentation can lead to the development of deep palmar abscesses with severe pain and systemic signs (fever, tachycardia)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a sore throat develops skin lesions, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely type of psoriasis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Guttate
The picture shows scattered drop-like papules and plaques suggestive of guttate psoriasis.
Guttate psoriasis is a distinct variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal) and is more common in children and adolescents than adults.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with complaints of nocturnal pruritus. Examination shows burrows over intertriginous areas, axilla, umbilicus, and in between the digits. Which of the following vectors is responsible for transmitting this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sarcoptes scabiei
The given clinical history of nocturnal pruritis and borrows over intertriginous areas, axilla, umbilicus, and in between digits is suggestive of scabies. It is caused by the itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei.
Scabies is caused by an infestation of Sarcoptes scabiei. It is transmitted by direct skin-to-skin contact and less frequently via contaminated clothes and bedding. They are seen more commonly in overcrowded areas, hostels, and schools, especially in unhygienic environments.

choices.text: An undisplaced supracondylar fracture of humerus
Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented to the OPD with the findings. He had suffered a fall on an outstretched hand one year back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus
The history of falling on an outstretched hand along with the gunstock deformity as seen in the image below are suggestive of malunion of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
Cubitus varus deformity or gun stock deformity is a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture that occurs due to malunion. When the distal fragment unites with an excessive backward tilt, there is hyperextension at the elbow.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with pain in the left loin. An intravenous urogram was done and the image is shown below. There is non-visualisation of the right kidney. Which of the following is a true statement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This abnormality can be due to compression of ureter by artery/vein on the same side
The given intravenous urogram (IVU) shows a dilated pelvicalyceal system and ureter on the left side suggesting a left-sided hydroureteronephrosis which occurs secondary to compression of distal ureter by a vessel- artery/vein.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with a complaint of dilated and tortuous veins in the left leg and mild pain while walking. On palpation, the vein is pulsatile. He had a history of road traffic accident, including a left leg fracture 10 years ago. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Arteriovenous (AV) fistula

This patient with a history of trauma and a recently developed pulsatile swelling of the same side has a traumatic arteriovenous fistula. An arteriovenous fistula is an abnormal communication between an artery and a vein and tends to occur when two structures are in proximity. Traumatic AVF can occur secondary to penetrating and blunt trauma. The most common traumatic AV fistula is a carotid-cavernous fistula secondary to the base of the skull fracture. Clinical features: pulsatile swelling and in chronic cases- limb lengthening, arterialisation of veins and heart failure. Large extremity fistula may present with skin warmth in contrast to cool extremity and signs of venous hypertension which is usually seen in varicosities.

choices.text: Untreated condition may lead to squamous cell carcinoma
