questions.text: A 25-year-old male came to OPD with a complaint of midline neck swelling which has been persistent for many years. Recently, it has become painful and inflamed. There has been a clear watery discharge from the wound since last week. On examination, the swelling moves with protrusion of the tongue and also on deglutition. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

They are remnants of thyroid tissue
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst which has been complicated by a sinus fistula. These are the remnants of thyroid tissue.
A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. It represents the persistence of the thyroglossal tract.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented to the trauma centre after suffering a road traffic accident. He is tachypneic with cold extremities. His BP on arrival is 90/50 mm Hg. Which of the following is true about the pathophysiology of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Increased vascular resistance
The above described patient with cold extremities, tachypnea and low blood pressure in a background of trauma has hypovolemic shock. In a patient with hypovolemic shock, there is increased systemic vascular resistance, decreased venous return(preload) and low mixed venous oxygen saturation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On evaluation, malignancy is suspected. Orchidectomy is done and the gross section is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Seminoma
The given cut section of testicular mass is homogenous, grey-white, and does not show haemorrhage or necrosis suggesting a diagnosis of seminoma.

questions.text:
Identify the procedure shown in the image:
ERCP- Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
CBD-Common bile duct
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ERCP+CBD stenting
The image shown is of ERCP and CBD stenting.
This is an invasive procedure similar to Upper Gl endoscopy. Ampulla of Vater is cannulated and then a contrast-filled dye is injected for evaluation of the biliary and pancreatic tree. After a pathology has been diagnosed in CBD, a CBD stent can be placed.

choices.text: Tube thoracostomy at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line
Needle decompression at 2nd intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. He is tachypneic and uses accessory neck muscles for respiration. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg. On percussion, the right chest is hyper-resonant. On auscultation, breath sounds could not be heard on the right chest. An urgent chest X-ray is done. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line

The above patient with hemodynamic instability, tachypnea and hyper-resonant sounds on percussion with absent breath sounds on auscultation along with the radiolucency and mediastinal shift on X-ray is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Immediate management is done with needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line.

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. She also gives a history of mood disorders and recurrent kidney stones. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Angiography of renal arteries

The given clinical scenario of recurrent kidney stones, mood disorder and features of hypercalcemia (polyuria, polydipsia) is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.
Investigations in primary hyperparathyroidism: Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for localising abnormal parathyroid glands.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient presents with dull aching pain over the back of his ankle. There is tenderness on firm palpation of the swelling. The following findings are seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Exostosis
According to the clinical scenario and given X-ray, Exostosis of the bone is the most likely diagnosis.
Exostoses can cause chronic pain ranging from mild to debilitatingly severe, depending on the shape, size, and location of the lesion. It is most commonly found in places like the ribs, where small bone growths form, but sometimes larger growths can grow on places like the ankles, knees, shoulders, elbows and hips. Very rarely are they on the skull. Exostoses can be seen in different types: calcaneal spurs, osteomyelitis, Charcot foot, osteochondroma, and hereditary multiple exostoses.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of renal calculi complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. X-ray shows subperiosteal resorption of 2nd and 3rd metacarpals and phalanges. On investigation, serum calcium and PTH were raised and phosphate levels were decreased. Which of the following investigations will help localise the primary pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

99Tc-Radiolabelled Sestamibi scan
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma arising sporadically. It is best localised using a 99Tc- Radiolabelled sestamibi scan.
Hyperparathyroidism is caused by elevated parathyroid hormone and is classified into primary, secondary, and tertiary types.

questions.text: A 26-year male presented to OPD with a deformity of the left hand. He had a past history of RTA in which he had injured the same limb 6 months back. There was hypothenar muscle atrophy and a fixed deformity where on opening his hand he is not able to extend the medial two fingers. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ulnar nerve
The given description is of a claw hand with hypothenar muscle atrophy classically seen in case of an ulnar nerve injury.
The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, interossei, and hypothenar muscles in the hand. The lumbricals are primarily responsible for the extension at the interphalangeal joints. Therefore, in ulnar nerve palsy, there is clawing of the medial two fingers.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presented to emergency with pain in the right lower quadrant. He was diagnosed with acute appendicitis. Which of the following is the most commonly used incision for appendectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Gridiron incision
The most commonly used incision for an appendectomy is McBurney’s Gridiron incision.
The incision is made at McBurney’s point (two-thirds from the umbilicus to the anterior superior iliac spine). They involve passing through all of the abdominal muscles, transversalis fascia, and then the peritoneum, before entering the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with decreased hearing. The skull radiograph shows the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paget’s disease
The given clinical scenario and cotton wool skull appearance on the radiograph are suggestive of Paget’s disease.
Paget’s disease is a disease of bone remodelling. Normally, osteoclasts remove the old bones while osteoblasts form new bones. In this disease, osteoclasts are more active than osteoblasts. Leading to more bone absorption than normal. The osteoblasts try to keep up by making new bone, but they overreact and make excess bone that is abnormally large, deformed and fits together haphazardly.

choices.text: Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma and neurosurgery consultation

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with a history of thromboembolic stroke is currently taking aspirin and warfarin. He is complaining of a headache and appears confused after a fall in the toilet last night. NCCT of the head was done. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma and neurosurgery consultation
The above clinical scenario and the plain computed tomography (CT) scan show a concave-convex- shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma (SDH). Since, the patient is on anticoagulants, reversal with Vitamin K, FFP and immediate neurosurgical consultation would be the next best step.
Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with pain in her right thigh and hips for three months. She was suspected to have hip tuberculosis. On examination, discrepancy in the length of her right limb was noticed. Which of the following stages of TB presents with apparent lengthening of the limb?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stage of synovitis
Apparent lengthening of the limb is seen in the stage of synovitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presented with a bright red velvety plaque on the floor of the mouth. Which of the following statements is correct about the diagnosis and management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Erythroplakia and biopsy
The given clinical scenario of a chronic smoker presenting with a bright red velvety plaque on the floor of the mouth is suggestive of erythroplakia and the next best step is to do an excision biopsy of the lesion.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female comes with complaints of severe chest pain since last night. She had gone to a party where she remembers binge drinking following which she had multiple episodes of vomiting which was also mixed with blood. On examination, she appeared sick and had fast breathing. Her BP-90/50 mg Hg, HR-112/min and crepitus can be palpated. An X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Esophageal perforation
The given clinical scenario with a history of recurrent episodes of vomiting mixed with blood, and now presenting with chest pain, hypotension, and palpable crepitus with a given X-ray showing pneumomediastinum is suggestive of esophageal perforation.

choices.text: Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic smoking came with complaints of ulcerative lesions on his lower lip for a year. On examination, there is a presence of a palpable ipsilateral submental node approximately 5*5 cm. Biopsy from the lesion was suggestive of squamous cell cancer. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
MRND-Modified radical neck dissection
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND
The given patient has a squamous cell carcinoma of the lip with a primary lesion on the lower lip with ipsilateral lymph node metastasis to the submental node. This patient will need resection of the primary lesion with reconstruction and modified radical neck dissection (MRND).
Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men from 50 to 70 years old but can be seen in younger patients. Risk factors include sunlight exposure, smoking, and tobacco use. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer. But commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with the following findings on her face. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acne vulgaris
The age of the patient and the presence of papules and pustules with an erythematous base on the face are suggestive of acne vulgaris.
Acne vulgaris is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. It is commonly seen in teenagers and young adults.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient was brought to the trauma centre following a road traffic accident. He was walking on the street when a car hit him from the side and severely injured his left knee. An X-ray of the knee joint showing distal femur and proximal tibia-fibula was done. Identify the given fracture:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Chauffeur fracture
Bumper fracture- fracture of the tibial plateau resulting from impact with a car bumper. It is due to a forced valgus injury of the knee when the car hits from the side.

questions.text: A patient with a history of recurrent pilonidal sinus underwent surgery as shown in the image. What kind of flap procedure is used here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rhomboid flap
The following image shows a rhomboid flap done in pilonidal sinus surgery.
A pilonidal sinus is defined as a blind track lined by granulation tissue leading from an epithelial surface to surrounding tissue. Pilonidal sinus disease, also called jeep/driver’s bottom, is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was evaluated for multiple skin tumors. The workup revealed defective nucleotide excision repair. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Xeroderma pigmentosum

The given clinical history of skin tumors with defective DNA nucleotide excision repair is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum.
Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair where there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with diffuse abdominal pain. Physical examination revealed rigidity and guarding. Abdominal X-ray demonstrated free air under the diaphragm. The patient was taken up for surgery and intraoperatively, ileal perforation was noted with gross contamination of the abdomen with enteric and purulent content. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Urgent surgical exploration with ileostomy
The clinical vignette with Ileal perforation and physical examination findings of rigidity and guarding suggest peritonitis due to perforation. The next best step in the management of this patient is urgent surgical exploration with an ileostomy.
Perforation of a viscus is a life-threatening condition that occurs following the rupture of the alimentary tract. Common causes include iatrogenic (surgery, scopes) blunt or penetrating injury, bowel obstruction, infections(TB, typhoid) peptic ulcer disease, corrosive agents, or particular medications

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the. Surgeon is attempting to identify the Calot’s triangle. Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cystic artery
In the given intra-op image during laparoscopic cholecystectomy the structure marked is a cystic artery.
During Laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the importance of achieving a critical view of safety is paramount for safe ligation and division of cystic duct and artery.

questions.text: A 24-year old male stated that he had fallen with his thumb extended and presented with a painful, swollen thumb. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Bennett fracture
The X-ray shows an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone known as Bennett fracture.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presented with a bilateral direct inguinal hernia. After evaluation, he was planned for laparoscopic hernia repair. The most common source of bleeding during this technique of surgery is from the
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Inferior epigastric artery
The most common source of bleeding during laparoscopic surgery (TAPP, TEP) is the inferior epigastric artery.
Laparoscopic hernia repair is particularly indicated in bilateral hernias, recurrent hernias after open repair, and in patients who prefer a minimally invasive approach. Techniques include transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair and totally extraperitoneal (TEP) repair.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presented with progressive swelling of the lower end of the femur. X-ray of this patient shows a Codman triangle. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Osteosarcoma

The given clinical scenario of a young patient with a tumour in the distal femur with a Codmnan’s triangle on X-ray suggests a probable diagnosis of osteosarcoma.
Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are common sites.

questions.text: A 30-year-old presents on postpartum day 10 with high-grade fever, malaise and pain in her left breast. She has been exclusively breastfeeding her child. She had presented to the OPD a few days back with mild pain and congestion of the breast and was prescribed oral analgesics and antibiotics. On examination, the left breast appears engorged and a fluctuant swelling is present. Ultrasound showed fluid collection. What is the next most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Breast abscess
A lactational mother with high-grade fever and fluctuant swelling which did not resolve with analgesics and antibiotics points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess.
The most common aetiology of breast abscess is Staph. Aureus and occurs commonly in lactational mothers. It occurs due to the colonisation of obstructed lactiferous ducts. It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant’s growing teeth.

questions.text: A patient fell from a train onto the railway tracks and injured both his legs severely. He was urgently taken to the hospital and the following procedure was done as shown in the image below. What is the rationale for performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Life saving procedure
The above patient shown in the image had undergone a below-knee amputation. In the background of trauma with a severely injured, crushed or septic limb amputation is a life- saving procedure.

questions.text: A male patient following an accident presented with complex injuries including degloving injuries of the foot and leg. What type of flap/graft was used during surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Thiersch graft
The image given shows a Thiersch graft which is also known as a split-thickness skin graft.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to a surgical emergency with complaints of severe epigastric pain for 1 day. On examination, HR was 120/min and BP was 100/60 mm Hg. On palpation, there is tenderness, guarding and rigidity. What is the probable cause of the condition shown in the X-ray below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hollow viscus perforation
The clinical scenario of hypotension and tachycardia with abdominal tenderness, guarding and rigidity with free air under the diaphragm in X-ray is indicative of hollow viscus perforation.
Acute abdomen is a common surgical emergency. Common causes include appendicitis, hollow viscus perforation, cholecystitis, and pancreatitis. An erect abdominal X-ray is commonly done as the first investigation. Free air under the diaphragm can result from hollow viscus perforation including Gastric, duodenal, small bowel and large bowel perforations.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presented to the OPD with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling over his abdomen for 1.5 years. She had a history of midline surgery done as a child. On examination, the swelling was 4 cm and was reducible with a palpable cough impulse. She is planned to undergo fascial closure with a mesh repair. What is the likely location of the mesh as shown in image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Onlay


The above clinical scenario of a reducible swelling with cough impulse and palpable defect in a patient with a previous surgery points toward a diagnosis of incisional hernia. Incisional hernias are repaired by fascial closure augmented with a mesh. It is an onlay type of mesh repair.

choices.text: Excision can be done if the patient makes a request

questions.text: A 45 year male presented to OPD with complaints of swelling on the upper back. It has been present for nearly a year and has not increased in size. On examination, the swelling is non pulsatile, and slip sign is positive approximately measuring 5*5 cm. Which of the following statements is likely true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Excision can be done if the patient makes a request
The clinical scenario of a 45-year-old male presenting with a non-pulsatile swelling on the upper back, which has not increased in size for nearly a year and measures approximately 5*5 cm with a positive slip sign, suggests a benign lesion like a lipoma. If the patient requests it, excision can be performed. Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue. It can occur anywhere and at any depth. It can be encapsulated or diffuse, superficial or deep.

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient diagnosed with hollow viscus perforation is taken up for laparotomy. Intraoperatively, a 2 cm-sized perforation is seen in the gastric region as shown below. How can this patient be managed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Omental pedicle repair
The given scenario of an alcoholic male patient of gastric perforation showing intra-op large 2 cm size perforation can be managed by an Omental pedicle repair.
Gastroduodenal perforations are a common surgical emergency in developing countries. Causes: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD), Smoking, alcohol, chronic analgesic use. Patients present with hypotension and signs and symptoms of peritonitis- tenderness, guarding and rigidity. Management: Multiple surgical options exist depending on the perforation’s location and size. Larger perforations and ulcers with fibrotic edges can be managed by an omental pedicle flap repair. A tongue of omentum is brought up to cover the ulcer defect and secured with a series of interrupted sutures. (Modified Graham’s patch)

choices.text: CT angiography followed by surgical intervention

questions.text: An elderly man with a chronic history of IV drug use presented with a progressively increasing swelling in the groin on the right side. It is is non fluctuant but pulsatile on examination. He has diminished pulses on the same side distal to the swelling. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CT angiography followed by surgical intervention
The patient most likely has a pseudoaneurysm of the femoral artery, caused by repeated penetrating injuries during intravenous drug administration. The recommended approach includes conducting a CT angiography for diagnosis, followed by surgical intervention.
In pseudoaneurysm, the intimal and medial layers are disrupted and the dilated segment is lined by adventitia only compared to a true aneurysm where all three layers are involved. It usually occurs secondary to trauma- arterial samples, arterial catheterization and IV drug users. It is usually pulsatile and systolic bruit can be heard on auscultation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presents with a scrotal swelling as shown in the image. The swelling is brilliantly transilluminant and the testes cannot be palpated separately. A CT scan was done which showed fluid collection in tunica vaginalis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hydrocele
In the above clinical scenario, there is a unilateral scrotal swelling in which the examiner cannot get above the swelling, and is transilluminant points towards a diagnosis of hydrocele.
Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. Hydrocele can be congenital or acquired. Congenital hydrocele is seen in children due to patent processes vaginalis. Acquired hydrocele can be secondary to inflammation or infection of the epididymis or testes. It is translucent on transillumination test and testes will not be separately palpable due to tense fluid collection. As it arises in the scrotum, it is possible to get above the swelling. Cough impulse is absent.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a known history of diabetes came with a wound on his foot. Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Trophic ulcer
The given picture showing an ulcer with punched-out edges over a pressure point is most likely that of a trophic ulcer/neuropathic ulcer.
A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that remain unnoticed but eventually develop into ulcers.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented to your OPD with genu varum and softening of skull bones. There is bony depression over the chest. What is the most likely deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vitamin D deficiency

The clinical scenario with genu varum, craniotabes and Harrison groove of the chest with the given lab parameters suggests rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency.
Rickets occurs due to a nutritional deficiency in vitamin D. Decrease in vitamin D levels leads to decreased calcium and phosphate due to reduced absorption. The decreased calcium stimulates increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) production. ALP level is increased as it is involved in bone mineralization.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with a direct inguinal hernia on the left side. He underwent open hernioplasty with mesh repair. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ilioinguinal nerve
The ilioinguinal nerve is most commonly injured within open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. The ilioinguinal nerve provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

questions.text: A 38-year-old lady, who was recently started on OCPs is referred to the dermatology OPD with hyperpigmented macules on the upper lip, malar region, and forehead as shown below. It is exacerbated by sun exposure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Melasma
The given clinical scenario of a woman on OCPs, who has hyperpigmented macules on her face, exacerbated by sun exposure is suggestive of melasma.
Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females. Melasma presents as hypermelanosis of the upper lip, malar regions, forehead, and chin. There may also be darkening of the nipples, linea alba, and groin. The lesions are usually bilateral and symmetrical.

questions.text: A young child presented to the emergency with pain in the right hand after falling from a height. An X-ray of the distal forearm and hand was done. The radiological image shows a physeal plate injury with a fracture extending to the metaphyses with the sparing of the epiphysis. What is the type of Salter-Harris physeal injury mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 II
The type of Salter-Harris injury mentioned above is type II injury.
Type II fracture is an intraarticular fracture. In a type II Salter harris fracture, the fracture line traverses the epiphyseal plate and then into the metaphyses. This damages the growth plate and results in growth disturbance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with pain abdomen. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen was done. What is the likely source of pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Kidney
The history of an elderly male presenting with pain abdomen and an axial CECT image showing renal lesions with irregular enhancement is suggestive of renal origin of pain likely renal cell carcinoma (RCC).
It is the most common malignant tumour of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It usually presents with painless gross hematuria, flank pain, or painless flank mass.

choices.text: Reduction of content, repair of the defect and reinforcement with a mesh

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with a left groin swelling for a few years. The swelling increases in size on standing and decreases while lying on the bed. On examination, the swelling has a positive cough impulse. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reduction of content, repair of the defect and reinforcement with a mesh
The given clinical scenario is an uncomplicated inguinal hernia. An uncomplicated inguinal hernia is repaired by the reduction of the content, repair of the defect and reinforcement with mesh placement(Lichtenstein mesh repair).
A hernia is a protrusion of the contents outside the cavity containing it. Groin hernias arising lateral to the inferior epigastric artery are indirect and hernia arising medial to it are direct inguinal hernias. Hernias have two cardinal features- reducibility and cough impulse. A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

choices.text: Calcium and PTH increase, phosphate is normal and ALP decreases
Calcium and phosphate decrease, PTH increases, and ALP is normal
Calcium and phosphate are normal, PTH increases and ALP decreases
Calcium, phosphate, PTH, ALP all are normal

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical parameters are consistent with osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Calcium, phosphate, PTH, ALP all are normal
Serum calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase, and parathyroid hormone levels are usually normal in osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought with complaints of headache, vomiting and neck stiffness for a few days. He had undergone a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt placement for hydrocephalus a year back. Which of the following is the most common cause of shunt malfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Shunt obstruction
Obstruction of the shunt is the most common cause of shunt malfunction.
A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

choices.text: It can progress to squamous cell cancer
Long duration antibiotics will improve the condition

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presented with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his scalp for 8 years. He gave a history of sustaining electric burns injury to the scalp 8 years back. The examination findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It can progress to squamous cell cancer
The given scenario and image show a long-standing ulcer with crusting and irregular borders can progress to Marjolin’s ulcer which is an aggressive type of squamous cell carcinoma.
Marjolin ulcers most commonly arise from burn scars. The most.common cell type identified is squamous cell carcinoma. All suspicious lesions should be biopsied. Confirmed cases of Marjolin ulcers should be excised with clear margins. Marjolin ulcers can be prevented with early excision and grafting of burn wounds. The prognosis is poor with a high rate of recurrence.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with lethargy. On examination, the child is unresponsive, unable to take oral feeds, eyes dry and sunken, and severely malnourished. What is the fluid of choice in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ringer’s lactate with 5

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulligravid patient came to the clinic complaining of irregular bleeding for the past month. What is the next best investigation you would perform?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Perform a urine pregnancy test

The next best investigation for a nulligravid patient presenting with irregular bleeding is a urine pregnancy test.
The first investigation to be done in a case of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is urine β-hCG estimation. This is done to rule out pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the chromosomal abnormality from the karyotyping shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Trisomy 18

The given karyotype is Trisomy 18- Edward’s syndrome.
Edward’s syndrome: Trisomy 18 results in Edward’s syndrome, in which a complete extra copy of chromosome 18 is inherited as a result of meiotic nondisjunction. The clinical features include micrognathia, low-set ears, prominent occiput, and rocker bottom feet Prenatal ultrasound reveals fetal growth restriction.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a newborn with weak lower limb pulses and strong upper limb pulses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Coarctation of Aorta
Coarctation of the aorta will be the diagnosis for a newborn with weak lower-limb pulses and strong upper-limb pulses.
Coarctation refers to a constriction or narrowing in the aorta, which can be proximal or distal to the ductus arteriosus. CoA usually presents either in infancy or in later childhood as incidental upper limb hypertension and disparity of pulses in the upper and lower limbs as radio-femoral delay.

questions.text: Until when can a postpartum intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) be inserted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

48 hours

Postpartum IUCD should be inserted within 48 hours.
An intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant.

questions.text: Which of the following signs suggests magnesium sulfate toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sluggish knee jerks
Loss of deep tendon reflexes like knee jerk reflex is a sign of magnesium toxicity.
Repeat injections of MgSO, are given only if knee jerks are present, urine output exceeds 30 ml/hr, and the and respiratory rate is more than 12/min.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is ventouse delivery contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Preterm
Ventouse delivery is contraindicated in preterm babies as It increases the risk of scalp avulsion or sub-aponeurotic haemorrhage.

questions.text: Positron emission tomography is based on which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Glucose metabolism
Positron emission tomography (PET) utilizes the mechanism of glucose metabolism.
PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer. It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.

questions.text: A woman presents to the outpatient department with spotting following IUD insertion. No pain or fever was reported. What is the next best step in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Give iron tablets and observe
In this scenario of a woman presenting to the outpatient department with spotting following an IUD insertion with no complaints of fever or pain, the next best step would be to give iron tablets and observe.
Spotting is a common side effect after IUD insertion and often resolves on its own without intervention. Since no other complications are present in this patient, there is no need to remove the IUD or prescribe any medications. The patient just needs to be under observation.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a phobic disorder. Which of the following defense mechanisms is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Displacement
Displacement is the defense mechanism in phobias. It is the shifting of emotions about one object/individual onto another object/individual.

questions.text: Banana and lemon signs are seen in which of the following fetal anomalies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neural tube defect
Banana and lemon signs are seen in case of neural tube defects.

Signs of neural tube defect on targeted sonography:
- Small biparietal diameter
- Ventriculomegaly
- Frontal bone scalloping or the lemon sign

questions.text: What is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gestational thrombocytopenia
The most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy is gestational thrombocytopenia. This may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following helps manage nausea and vomiting during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Taking small and frequent meals
Taking small and frequent meals during pregnancy can help alleviate nausea and vomiting, commonly known as morning sickness.
Pregnancy can affect glucose metabolism, causing fluctuations in blood sugar levels, which may trigger nausea. Eating small, frequent meals helps maintain more stable blood sugar levels, reducing the likelihood of nausea associated with hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Weight for height
A low weight for height indicates wasting in a child.
Nutritional status is often assessed in terms of anthropometry

questions.text: Ga-68PSMA is used to diagnose which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prostate cancer
Radio-labeled ligands- Gallium (Ga68) attached to the prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA)can be helpful in identifying prostatic cancer.
Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) is a specific prostate epithelial cell membrane antigen, showing increased expression in prostate cancers, which is also a potential target for monoclonal antibody therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is most likely to be seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypokalemia
Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is associated with hypokalemic hypochloremic alkalosis.
Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e. hypokalemia hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Persistent vomiting secondary to gastric outlet obstruction results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl). Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Nat and HCO3. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.

choices.text: A temperature of >100.4 F, 12 hours after delivery
A temperature of >100.4 F, 48 hours after delivery
A temperature of >100.4 F, 24 hours after delivery
A temperature of >100.4 F, 7 days after delivery

questions.text: Puerperal pyrexia can be diagnosed if a woman has:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A temperature of >100.4 F, 24 hours after delivery
Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of >100.4 °F (38) °C or higher) on 2 separate occasions at 24 hours apart (excluding the first 24 hours) within the first 10 days following delivery.
In the first 24 hours, a slight rise in temperature is not uncommon and hence the first 24 hours are excluded to define puerperal pyrexia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most radiosensitive organ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Testes
Among the given options, testes is the most radiosensitive organ.
The radiosensitivity is higher in cases where the proliferation is high. In the case of the testes, it contains a high number of clonal cells since it is a reproductive organ. Thus, among the given options testes is the most radiosensitive organ.

questions.text: Calculate the mid-parental height of a male child whose father’s and mother’s height are 183 cm and 175 cm, respectively.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

185.5 cm
The mid-parental height for a male child with a father who is 183 cm and a mother who is 175 cm tall will be 185.5 cm.
Mid-parental height for a male child = (Mother’s height + Father’s height/2) +6.5

Calculation:
Mother’s height = 175 cms
Father’s height = 183 cms
Mid parental height = (183+175/2)+6.5 185.5 cm
Mid-parental height for a female child = (Mother’s height + Father’s height/2)-6.5

questions.text: Where is Ovoid and tandem radiotherapy used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Cervical cancer
Ovoid and tandem radiotherapy is used for cervical cancer.
Ovoid and tandem brachytherapy is a combination technique where a tandem applicator and ovoid applicators are used for radiation treatment.

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the hospital with an umbilical hernia, dry, rough skin, rough hair, and macroglossia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cretinism
The clinical vignette with signs and symptoms of umbilical hernia, dry, rough skin, rough hair, and macroglossia is suggestive of Cretinism.
Cretinism is a condition characterized by irreversible abnormalities in intellectual development. Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can be neurological cretinism or myxedematous cretinism. It is associated with severe, irreversible mental retardation.

questions.text: According to Caldwell and Moloy’s classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Android pelvis
According to Caldwell and Moloy’s classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with the android pelvis.
The female pelvis can be divided into 4 types based on the pelvic inlet’s shape as follows:
- Gynecoid
- Anthropoid
- Android
- Platypelloid

questions.text: Which is the most common cancer in Indian women?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Breast cancer
The most common cancer in Indian women is breast cancer.
Breast cancer has a prevalence of 92.6 per 100,000 population while the prevalence of Ca cervix is 72 per 100000 population.

questions.text: Inability to recognize familiar faces is known as ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prosopagnosia
Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize familiar faces
In humans, storage and recognition of faces is more strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals, though the left lobe is also active. Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia, the inability to recognize faces.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive device given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lippe
The contraceptive device shown in the image above is a Lippe’s loop.
Lippes Loop is a 1st generation IUD that comes in four sizes – A, B, C and D. It is an S-shaped device, usually made of polyethene. The tail, which is usually made of fine nylon, projects into the vagina after insertion. The larger loops, used in multiparous women, have higher rates of removal due to side effects but have greater anti-fertility effects.

questions.text: A young woman came to the clinic requesting a post-coital pill. Which of the following would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Levonorgestrel
Levonorgestrel can be prescribed to a young woman requesting a post-coital pill.
Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, it can also be administered in two doses of 0.75 mg. The first dose is taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, and the 2nd dose is taken 12 hours apart. The tablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios can outlet forceps be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Head at perineum
Outlet forceps can be used when the head of the fetus is at the perineum.
Outlet forceps/ Wrigley’s forceps is light, about a third of the weight of ordinary long-curved forceps. The instrument is short which is due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a past history of tuberculosis presents to the OPD with complaints of chronic cough, occasional hemoptysis, and persistent chest pain. Chest X-ray shows the following lesion. It has been observed that when the patient’s position changes, the air within the lesion changes as well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Aspergilloma
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a past history of tuberculosis with an X-ray showing Monod’s sign is suggestive of aspergilloma. The gas/air surrounding a mobile fungal ball or mycetoma (usually an aspergilloma) in an already-existing lung cavity is referred to as the Monod sign.
Aspergilloma or fungal ball is a late manifestation of chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) caused by Aspergillus species. A fungal ball is formed within the pulmonary cavity of CPA by the peeled-off inner layer of the cavity.

questions.text: A person experiences an intense fear of tall buildings and high places. Which of the following terms is used to describe this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Acrophobia
Acrophobia is the fear of heights.

questions.text: What is the daily fluid requirement for a 3-day-old child weighing 1300 gms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

130 ml/kg/day
The daily fluid requirement for this 3-day-old child weighing 1300 g is 130 ml/kg/day (120-130 ml/kg/day)

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 patient at 17 weeks of gestation comes for a routine antenatal visit. Her blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. A repeat blood pressure after 6 hours measures 148/92 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Chronic hypertension

In this scenario of hypertension in a patient with a gestational age <20> 140/90 mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A nulligravida presents to the OPD with uterine prolapse. No cystocele or rectocele were noted. What procedure will you perform?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Abdominal sling surgery
For a nulligravid woman with uterine prolapse and no cystocele or rectocele, we will perform an abdominal sling surgery.
Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

questions.text: Which of the following channels is defective in a child with a CFTR gene defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CI-
A child with a CFTR (Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein) mutation will have cystic fibrosis. Abnormalities in the CFTR gene lead to defective chloride (Cl-) channels.
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal-recessive disorder in children and adults. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion on chromosome 7q. This encodes CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) protein, which is involved in the regulation of Cl- channel. This mutation results in a lack of Cl- secretion and an increase in ENaC-mediated Na+ and water reabsorption.

questions.text: Early cord clamping is done in which of the following cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rh negative mother
Early cord clamping will be done in the case of a Rh-negative mother.
Early cord clamping is generally carried out in the first 60 seconds after birth.

questions.text: The inheritance pattern shown below is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mitochondrial
The Inheritance pattern shown above is mitochondrial inheritance.
Mitochondrial inheritance:
- Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome. 
- Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization. 
- Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.
- These diseases include: Mitochondrial encephalopathy, Lactic acidosis and Stroke like episodes (MELAS) and other disorders tabulated below (mnemonic: KLMNOP).

questions.text: What marker is regularly monitored in the management of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

β-hCG
The marker used in the monitoring of ectopic pregnancy is ẞ- hCG
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a glycoprotein. It can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8- 9 days post-fertilization. Maximum levels in blood and urine are found between 60-70 days of pregnancy. It disappears from circulation within 2 weeks following delivery.

questions.text: A patient underwent the following investigation for suspected malignancy. Which of the following compounds is used in this investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fluorodeoxyglucose
The image shows a positron-emission tomography (PET) scan. PET involves the use of a radiolabeled bio-compound such as 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is injected intravenously.
It is based on the principle that tumor cells have a high metabolic rate and can metabolize FDG. However, tumor cells can metabolize FDG only to FDG-6-phosphate, and no further. Hence, it accumulates in tumor cells and can be detected and quantified.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gilbert syndrome
Gilbert syndrome is associated with Inherited unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: What is the ideal number of recommended ANC visits during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

12-14

The recommended ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14 during pregnancy.
The generally recommended ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14:
- Monthly visits up to 28 weeks
- Two weekly visits between 28-36 weeks
- Weekly visits from 36 weeks onward.
- This means a total of 12-14 visits.

questions.text: What is the location of the Bartholin cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posterior 1/3 of the vulva

Bartholin cysts are located in the posterior 1/3 of the vulva.
The Bartholin glands are known as the greater vestibular glands in females. These glands are located in the posterior part of the vestibule and open through a duct into the vaginal orifice at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They secrete mucus during sexual arousal for lubrication. They are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presented with symptoms of low mood, loss of interest, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances for the past 1 week. She has a history of two similar episodes over the last 5 years. She has no history of elated mood, racing thoughts, or decreased sleep. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Recurrent depressive disorder
The given clinical scenario of low mood, loss of interest, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances with a past history of two similar episodes is suggestive of recurrent depressive disorder.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the given image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Miliary tuberculosis
The above radiograph depicts the miliary pattern seen in tuberculosis.
Miliary tuberculosis is a form of disseminated pulmonary tuberculosis that occurs when organisms draining through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. It can result from progressive primary disease, reactivation of latent foci, and iatrogenic exposure (lithotripsy, urethral catheterization, cardiac valve homograft placement, and solid organ transplantation).

choices.text: It is used to measure infrared rays emitted by red blood cells
It is used for the localisation of calcified plaque
It is used to measure systolic blood pressure
It is used to measure blood flow and detect blood flow abnormalities in the blood vessel

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the device shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

It is used to measure blood flow and detect blood flow abnormalities in the blood vessel
The given image is of a handheld doppler device. It is used to measure blood flow and detect blood flow abnormalities in the blood vessel.
The Doppler ultrasound device utilizes the doppler effect to assess the movement of red blood cells within blood vessels. The doppler effect is the change in frequency or wavelength of a wave in relation to an observer moving relative to the wave source. The device emits ultrasound waves that reflect off moving red blood cells. The frequency shift between the transmitted and received sound waves is used to calculate the velocity and direction of blood flow.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. After eating her food in one go, she induces forceful vomiting. Her BMI is 27 kg/m2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bulimia nervosa

The given scenario of a 16-year-old girl with intense food cravings followed by self-induced vomiting and a BMI of 27 kg/m², points towards the diagnosis of bulimia nervosa.
Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Jejunal atresia
The given radiograph shows a triple bubble sign which is seen in jejunal atresia.
Jejunal atresia is a congenital anomaly which presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension soon after birth. A small amount of meconium may be passed despite the atresia. Plain X-ray abdomen shows multiple air-fluid levels, known as the triple bubble sign. Contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies. In most cases, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is done. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis

questions.text: A woman with a non-recurring indication of a previous lower segment cesarean section now presents with an occipitoposterior fetal position. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Attempt a normal vaginal delivery
In a woman with a non-recurring indication of lower segment cesarean sections who now presents with an occipitoposterior fetal position, the next step of management would be to try to attempt a vaginal delivery.
Occipitoposterior position is an abnormal position of the vertex and can undergo normal labor in favorable circumstances.

questions.text: When is cord clamping ideally done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Within 1-3 minutes
As per the AMTSL guidelines, cord clamping is practised within 1-3 minutes of the delivery of the fetus.
Delayed cord clamping is done 30 to 60 seconds after birth in all the babies. This increases the amount of blood flowing from mother to baby which decreases the risk of anaemia in later life, improves hemodynamic stability, decreases the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis, intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants, and also decreases the need for transfusions and inotropic support.

questions.text: Which of the following is given to prevent neural tube defects in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Folic Acid
Folic acid (Vitamin B9) is given to prevent the incidence of neural tube defects.
Folic acid deficiency is implicated in neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.
As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, during the period of pre-conception up to the first trimester, women are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets daily to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is in labour, and during delivery, the baby’s head is delivered, but the shoulders get stuck. The baby’s head is at the introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Shoulder dystocia

This clinical vignette of a 28-year-old woman in labour with the baby’s head at the introitus and the shoulders being stuck is suggestive of shoulder dystocia.
Shoulder dystocia, defined as a head-to-body delivery time >60 seconds, occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory respectively. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum.

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

6 months
Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for 6 months.
Breastfeeding should be started as soon as possible after birth. For an infant to be called exclusively breastfed, pre- lacteal feeds and even water are not to be given. However, giving vitamin drops, if indicated, is included under the definition of exclusive breastfeeding.
